comment_3:
A sweet anthemic gem. 

A bird with broken wings, black feathers against the bleak backdrop of a coal black night, yearning to break free. And that funny little paradoxical refrain - "...into the light of a dark black night." The mental image is a sliver of moon or winking stars, but really I take it to mean that no matter how metaphorically dark your surroundings, there is always a dim glimmer to be found. We all have our blackbird moments, and broken wings or not, it's up to us to hobble our way towards the light.

comment_46: Written by Paul on his farm in Scotland, the original inspiration was from a well-known piece by Bach, that he never knew the title of, that he and George used to play as kids. Originally Paul had in mind a black women, rather than a bird. These were the days of the civil-rights movement, something that Paul and the other Beatles cared passionately about. Consequently, Paul is really writing this song to a black woman, who was experiencing the many associated problems concerning civil-rights in the United States. Paul is saying to his woman (or any black woman) to keep trying, to keep the faith, and that there is hope. Rather than using specifics, Paul used a blackbird, that became symbolic so that it could be applied to any situation or problem.

So. I don't really care what it's actually about.

When I hear this song I see a father or other guardian bestowing his own wings on to a son, thereby sacrificing his own freedom, his own life to enable the next generation to live.

the singer is passing the baton to the next runner, if you catch my drift.

and he's sad about the sacrifice but he rationalizes it by saying (A) death is inevitable and (B) the kid deserves it, has earned his freedom.

the dark black night in my scenario symbolizes the world. and the light of the dark black night is the positive, the freedom, the good qualities of a frightening, dangerous world.

"all your life you were only waiting..."
this part means that the subject, the child, his life up to that point has been preparation for taking the elder's wings and learning to fly for himself.

but I couldn't tell you why he's a blackbird.

except that perhaps the singer realizes that even his offspring will die and is doomed to make the same passage that the singer himself is going through.

so yeah. passage into adulthood, passage into death, and filial love are the themes in this song for me.

so yeah. that's what it is.

comment_158:
John Lennon wrote this, and it is characteristically metaphorical, enigmatic, deep and speaks to social justice. 

First, some questions:

Q01. Why is it a blackbird and not a hawk, falcon or eagle that are superior birds of flight?

Q02. Why is it a blackbird and not a bluebird or redbird?

Q03. How can a bird with broken wings fly?

Q04. Since birds are born with the ability to fly, why does the bird need to learn to fly?

Q05. Why does the bird learn to fly all its life and not just once?

Q06. Why was the bird waiting for this moment to arise?

Q07. What do sunken eyes represent?

Q08. How can sunken eyes learn to see?

Q09. Since birds are born with the ability to see, why does the bird need to learn to see?

Q10. Again, why all your life and not just once?

Q11. Given the parrallelism, what is the connection between flying and seeing?

Q12. Why was the bird waiting for this moment to be free?

Q13. What is the light of the dark black night?

And then, some answers: 

A01. The blackbird is a commonplace bird that represents ordinary human beings with ordinary abilities. 

A02. The bird is black because it is esoteric. 

A03. The broken-winged bird does not fly physically in body but psychically in spirit. 

A04. The bird must learn to fly because it is not external physical flight, but internal spirit flight, contrary to societal indoctrination.

A05. The bird must learn to fly all its life because it is the real life of non-physical spirit and not the illusory life of physical matter. 

A06. The bird was waiting for this moment to arise because it had to overcome social conditioning and its repressive values, attitudes, beliefs and unexamined assumptions and presumptions. 

A07. Sunken eyes represent tunnel vision, blinkered vision, restricted vision, distorted vision, limited vision. 

A08. Sunken eyes can learn to see non-physically, internally, within, psychically. 

A09. The bird must learn to see because it is not external physical sight, but internal non-physical sight, contrary to societal indoctrination which is a heavy burden and constant distraction. 

A10. The bird must learn to see all its life because it is the real life of spirit in the ever-present now and not the illusory life of matter.

A11. Flying and seeing (flight and sight) are both metaphors for the meditative state of consciousness, a/k/a cosmic consciousness. 

A12. The bird was waiting for this moment to be free in the sense of the inner freedom that results from inner vision and the flight to higher consciousness.

A13. The light of the dark black night is the sourceless light, illumination and enlightenment that can result from personal, first-hand, immediate, unmediated, existential experience of the innermost center of being, whereas only darkness and blackness appear on the external surface. 

In summary, every human lifetime on Earth begins with a veil of amnesia that can be penetrated with the practice of meditation to reach the state of meditative consciousness. Everyone is always illuminated in spirit, just they don't remember it. 

The Blackbird song is a celebration of freedom and joy, no less than Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, Final Movement, Ode to Joy a/k/a Ode to Freedom.

The song is extremely simple and can be interpreted as anyone wishes to see, however the true nature pertains to the Rock n" Roll movement.

Rock n' Roll was cocked & loaded as the invention of the radio ripened to a substantial potential, reaching a mass numbers of listeners worldwide.

At this moment, it was fired upon the world, attracting millions to the new sound, and in its wake, engulfing open minds with it's message. In the beginning the message was "good times, dancing, and fun", but we all know Rock n' Roll (and other spawns of the movement like Hip Hop and Pop) snowballed into a barrage of "sex, drugs, and immorality" which, along with technology to empower the spread, has led society into it's Godless nature. 

There's always been Evil, but by this, it was fueled to run rampant to a point where we wonder "what is going on in this world?!?!".

The Blackbird, symbolizes the dark side buried within us. It is being encouraged to "arise" "at this moment" (when Darkness has overcome it's boundaries) and see a new way of life, "free" from the limitations of following God's Law: "flying to the light of the dark, black night".

Should I remind you, Lucifer is known as the "Prince of Light", and in some perspectives the giver of free will. 

In Audio Only this can translate "into the light of the dark, Black Knight.
